fr:title.text: Duality theorems for coherent algebraic sheaves › The duality theorem

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Duality theorems for coherent algebraic sheaves › The duality theorem

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In this section, X denotes a non-singular projective variety of dimension n.
The fundamental class \varepsilon _X of \operatorname {H}^n(X,\Omega _X^n) is a basis of this vector space.
The proof of this statement will be given later on.
The homomorphism in is an isomorphism.
In particular, we recover the following result of Serre:

Let E be an algebraic vector bundle on X, and \mathcal {O}_X(E) the sheaf of germs of regular sections of X. Then we have canonical isomorphisms ([Trans.] This equation is labelled (5.3) in the original copy of the notes, but this seems to be a typo, since a later equation shares the same number, and any references to (5.3) seem to indeed point to the later equation instead of this one.) (\operatorname {H}^p(X,\mathcal {O}_X(E)))' = \operatorname {H}^{n-p}(X,\Omega _X^n\otimes \mathcal {O}_X(E')).
It suffices to apply and Corollary 1 of Proposition 1.
and will follow from the following claim:

It remains only to prove , which will follow in a purely formal way from some elementary facts summarised in the following lemmas. Here we suppose that X is a closed subset (singular or not) of the projective space \mathbf {P} of dimension r. We use the notation \mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(m) to denote the sheaf on \mathbf {P} denoted by \mathcal {O}(m) in [Ser1955], and the notation \mathcal {O}_X(m) for the analogous sheaf on X.
The statement of is true if X=\mathbf {P} and \mathscr {F}=\mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(m).

This lemma can be proved by a direct calculation. The explicit calculation of the \operatorname {H}^i(\mathbf {P},\mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(m)) can be found in [Ser1955], but it also can be done in a simpler way. Computing the cup product \operatorname {H}^i(\mathbf {P},\mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(m))\times \operatorname {H}^j(\mathbf {P},\mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(m)') \to \operatorname {H}^{i+j}(\mathbf {P},\mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(m+m')) (which is necessary to calculate the pairing in ) does not present any difficulty.
Every coherent algebraic sheaf \mathscr {F} on X is isomorphic to a sheaf that is some quotient of \mathcal {O}_X(-m)^k, and we can take m to be as large as we wish.
This follows from the fact that \mathscr {F}\otimes \mathcal {O}_X(m) is "generated by its sections" for large enough m; see [Ser1955].

The first claim follows from the explicit calculations mentioned above; for the second, we note that we have an isomorphism \operatorname {Ext}_{\mathcal {O}_X}^i(X;\mathcal {O}_X(-m),\mathscr {B}) = \operatorname {H}^i(X,\mathscr {B}\otimes \mathcal {O}(m)) (by Corollary 1 of Proposition 1), whence the conclusion, by a well-known result of [Ser1955].
Combining the previous two lemmas, we find:

Let i>0. Then the functor \mathscr {F}\mapsto \operatorname {H}^{r-i}(\mathbf {P},\mathscr {F}) on the category of coherent algebraic sheaves on \mathbf {P} is coeffaceable, and so too is the functor \operatorname {Ext}_{\mathcal {O}_X}^i(X;\mathscr {F},\mathscr {B}) on the category of coherent algebraic sheaves on X.

Let \mathscr {A} and \mathscr {B} be coherent algebraic sheaves on X, and let \mathscr {A}(m)=\mathscr {A}\otimes \mathcal {O}_X(m). Then, for large enough m, the canonical homomorphism \operatorname {Ext}_{\mathcal {O}_X}^i(X;\mathscr {A}(-m),\mathscr {B}) \to \operatorname {H}^0(X,\mathscr {E}\kern -1.5pt\mathit {xt}_{\mathcal {O}_X}^i(\mathscr {A}(-m),\mathscr {B})) = \operatorname {H}^0(X,\mathscr {E}\kern -1.5pt\mathit {xt}_{\mathcal {O}_X}^i(\mathscr {A},\mathscr {B})(m)) is an isomorphism.

This follows immediately from the spectral sequence in applied to \mathscr {A}(-m) and \mathscr {B}, since we then have that E_2^{p,q}(\mathscr {A}(-m),\mathscr {B}) = \operatorname {H}^p(X,\mathscr {E}\kern -1.5pt\mathit {xt}_{\mathcal {O}_X}^q(\mathscr {A}(-m),\mathscr {B})) = \operatorname {H}^p(X,\mathscr {E}\kern -1.5pt\mathit {xt}_{\mathcal {O}_X}^q(\mathscr {A},\mathscr {B})(m)) which is zero for p>0 and large enough m.

We now prove in the case where X=\mathbf {P}. We will first prove that is an isomorphism for p=n; since both sides are then left-exact functors (since \operatorname {H}^{r+i}(\mathbf {P},\mathscr {F})=0), it follows from that it suffices to prove the claim for \mathscr {F}=\mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(-m), but this is covered by . Since the homomorphisms in are functorial and compatible with the coboundary maps, and since, for p<n, both sides of are coeffaceable functors in \mathscr {F} (the corollary to Lemmas 3 and 4), it follows, by a standard argument, that is an isomorphism for all p. This proves the duality theorem for the projective space.
The statement of is true if X=\mathbf {P} and \mathscr {F}=\mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(m).

This lemma can be proved by a direct calculation. The explicit calculation of the \operatorname {H}^i(\mathbf {P},\mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(m)) can be found in [Ser1955], but it also can be done in a simpler way. Computing the cup product \operatorname {H}^i(\mathbf {P},\mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(m))\times \operatorname {H}^j(\mathbf {P},\mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(m)') \to \operatorname {H}^{i+j}(\mathbf {P},\mathcal {O}_\mathbf {P}(m+m')) (which is necessary to calculate the pairing in ) does not present any difficulty.
